sentence.value: Jerry Michael Linenger (born January 16, 1955), M.D., M.S.S.M., M.P.H., Ph.D., is a retired Captain in the United States Navy Medical Corps, and a former NASA astronaut who flew on the Space Shuttle and Space Station Mir.

sentence.value: Born January 16, 1955, and raised in Eastpointe, Michigan, he is married to the former Kathryn M. Bartmann of Arlington Heights, Illinois; they have four children.

sentence.value: He received a Bachelor of Science degree in bioscience from the United States Naval Academy in 1977, a doctorate in medicine from Wayne State University School of Medicine in 1981, a Master of Science degree in systems management from the University of Southern California in 1988, a Master of Public Health degree in health policy from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 1989 and a Doctor of Philosophy degree in epidemiology from the University of North Carolina in 1989.

sentence.value: In completing his first mission, Linenger logged 10 days, 22 hours, 51 minutes in space, completed 177 orbits, and traveled over 4.5 million miles.

sentence.value: Following his first mission, in January 1995, he began training at the Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Center in Star City, Russia, in preparation for a long-duration stay aboard the Russian Space Station Mir.

sentence.value: All training was conducted using the Russian language, and consisted of learning all Mir space station systems (life support/electrical/communication/attitude control/computer systems), simulator training, Soyuz launch/return vehicle operations, and spacewalk water tank training.

sentence.value: He also trained as chief scientist to conduct the entire U.S. science program, consisting of over one-hundred planned experiments in various disciplines.
sentence.annotated-sentence: He also trained as [[chief scientist|Chief_technology_officer]] to conduct the entire [[U.S.|U.S._Open_Badminton_Championships]] [[science|Science]] program, consisting of over one-hundred planned [[experiments|Experiment]] in [[various disciplines|Discipline]].
sentence.pattern_crowdsource: He also trained as chief scientist to conduct the entire U.S. science program, consisting of over one-hundred planned experiments in various disciplines.

sentence.value: A sampling includes: medicine (humoral immunity, sleep monitoring, radiation dosimetry), physiology (spatial orientation/performance changes during long duration flight), epidemiology (microbial surface sampling), metallurgy (determination of metal diffusion coefficients), oceanography/geology/limnology/physical science (photographic survey (over 10,000 photos) of the Earth), space science (flame propagation), microgravity science (behavior of fluids, critical angle determination).

sentence.value: Linenger launched aboard U.S. Space Shuttle Atlantis (STS-81) on January 12, 1997, remained on board the space station with two Russian cosmonauts upon undocking of the Shuttle, and eventually returned upon a different mission of Atlantis (STS-84) on May 24, 1997—spending a total of 132 days, 4 hours, 1 minute in space—the longest duration flight of an American male at that time.
sentence.tree: nsubj(launched/VBD-2,Linenger/NNP-1) ccomp(remained/VBD-17,launched/VBD-2) nn(Atlantis/NNP-7,U.S./NNP-4) nn(Atlantis/NNP-7,Space/NNP-5) nn(Atlantis/NNP-7,Shuttle/NNP-6) prep_aboard(launched/VBD-2,Atlantis/NNP-7) appos(Atlantis/NNP-7,STS-81/NN-9) prep_on(launched/VBD-2,January/NNP-12) num(January/NNP-12,12/CD-13) num(January/NNP-12,1997/CD-15) prep_on(remained/VBD-17,board/NN-19) det(station/NN-22,the/DT-20) nn(station/NN-22,space/NN-21) tmod(remained/VBD-17,station/NN-22) num(cosmonauts/NNS-26,two/CD-24) amod(cosmonauts/NNS-26,Russian/JJ-25) prep_with(station/NN-22,cosmonauts/NNS-26) prep_upon(cosmonauts/NNS-26,undocking/NN-28) det(Shuttle/NNP-31,the/DT-30) prep_of(undocking/NN-28,Shuttle/NNP-31) advmod(returned/VBD-35,eventually/RB-34) conj_and(remained/VBD-17,returned/VBD-35) det(mission/NN-39,a/DT-37) amod(mission/NN-39,different/JJ-38) prep_upon(returned/VBD-35,mission/NN-39) prep_of(mission/NN-39,Atlantis/NNP-41) appos(Atlantis/NNP-41,STS-84/NN-43) prep_on(returned/VBD-35,May/NNP-46) num(May/NNP-46,24/CD-47) num(May/NNP-46,1997/CD-49) dep(May/NNP-46,spending/VBG-51) det(total/NN-53,a/DT-52) dobj(spending/VBG-51,total/NN-53) num(days/NNS-56,132/CD-55) prep_of(total/NN-53,days/NNS-56) num(hours/NNS-59,4/CD-58) appos(days/NNS-56,hours/NNS-59) num(minute/NN-62,1/CD-61) npadvmod(spending/VBG-51,minute/NN-62) prep_in(spending/VBG-51,space/NN-64) det(flight/NN-69,the/DT-66) amod(flight/NN-69,longest/JJS-67) nn(flight/NN-69,duration/NN-68) dep(remained/VBD-17,flight/NN-69) det(male/NN-73,an/DT-71) amod(male/NN-73,American/JJ-72) prep_of(flight/NN-69,male/NN-73) det(time/NN-76,that/DT-75) prep_at(male/NN-73,time/NN-76)

sentence.value: During his stay aboard Space Station Mir, Linenger became the first American to conduct a spacewalk from a foreign space station and in a non-American made spacesuit.
sentence.tree: poss(stay/NN-3,his/PRP$-2) prep_during(American/JJ-13,stay/NN-3) nn(Mir/NNS-7,Space/NN-5) nn(Mir/NNS-7,Station/NNP-6) prep_aboard(stay/NN-3,Mir/NNS-7) nsubj(American/JJ-13,Linenger/NNP-9) cop(American/JJ-13,became/VBD-10) det(American/JJ-13,the/DT-11) amod(American/JJ-13,first/JJ-12) aux(conduct/VB-15,to/TO-14) xcomp(American/JJ-13,conduct/VB-15) xcomp(American/JJ-13,conduct/VB-15) conj_and(conduct/VB-15,conduct/VB-15) det(spacewalk/NN-17,a/DT-16) dobj(conduct/VB-15,spacewalk/NN-17) det(station/NN-22,a/DT-19) amod(station/NN-22,foreign/JJ-20) nn(station/NN-22,space/NN-21) prep_from(conduct/VB-15,station/NN-22) det(spacesuit/NN-28,a/DT-25) dep(made/VBN-27,non-American/JJ-26) amod(spacesuit/NN-28,made/VBN-27) prep_in(conduct/VB-15,spacesuit/NN-28)

sentence.value: During the five-hour walk, he and his Russian colleague tested for the first time ever the newly designed Orlan-M Russian-built spacesuit, installed the Optical Properties Monitor (OPM) and Benton dosimeter on the outer surface of the station, and retrieved for analysis on Earth numerous externally-mounted material-exposure panels.

sentence.value: The three crewmembers also performed a "flyaround" in the Soyuz spacecraft-undocking from one docking port of the station, manually flying to and redocking the capsule at a different location-thus making Linenger the first American to undock from a space station aboard two different spacecraft (U.S. Space Shuttle and Russian Soyuz).

sentence.value: While living aboard the space station, Linenger and his two Russian crewmembers faced numerous difficulties: the most severe fire ever aboard an orbiting spacecraft, failures of onboard systems (oxygen generator, carbon dioxide scrubbing, cooling line loop leaks, communication antenna tracking ability, urine collection and processing facility), a near collision with a resupply cargo ship during a manual docking system test, loss of station electrical power, and loss of attitude control resulting in a slow, uncontrolled "tumble" through space.

sentence.value: In spite of these challenges and added demands on their time (in order to carry out the repair work), they still accomplished all mission goals-spacewalk, flyaround, and one-hundred percent of the planned U.S. science experiments.

sentence.value: In completing the nearly five-month mission, Linenger logged approximately 50 million miles (the equivalent of over 110 round trips to the Moon and back), more than 2,000 orbits around the Earth, and traveled at an average speed of 18,000 miles per hour.

sentence.value: Linenger retired from NASA and the U.S. Navy in January 1998, and presently lives with his family in northern Michigan.
sentence.annotated-sentence: [[Linenger|Jerry_M._Linenger]] retired from [[NASA|NASA]] and [[the U.S. Navy|United_States_Navy]] in [[January 1998|1998]], and presently lives with [[his family|Family]] in [[northern Michigan|Northern_Michigan]].
